title: R45390
content: Some stakeholders debate the role of the private sector in providing healthcare for veterans. Views range from advocating for all care to be provided by the VA to utilizing private sector providers for specialized services or to address access barriers. Concerns exist about the potential impact on the quality of care within the VA system. Some stakeholders debate the role of the private sector in providing healthcare for veterans, with concerns about the impact on the quality of care within the VA system. Private sector community providers may lack necessary training for specialized care, but competition could potentially improve services in the VA system. Balancing care between the VA health care system and non-VA providers remains a challenge for policymakers and stakeholders. The VA MISSION Act of 2018 addressed the issue of providers for veterans by establishing the Veterans Community Care Program. This legislation aimed to improve the delivery of healthcare to veterans by involving private sector community providers. The report provides a brief history of legislative changes to community care for veterans, highlighting the establishment of the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) under the VA MISSION Act. It outlines the major provisions of the Act and includes implementation and reporting deadlines. Since the early 1920s, Congress has authorized the VA to contract for care in the community, including language in the World War Veterans Act of 1924. The VA's Hometown Medical Care Program, established in FY1946, allowed for contracting with private facilities in exceptional cases. The Hometown Medical Program, also known as the fee-basis care program, was established by the VA in FY1946. It involved contracts with state medical societies or designated agencies for authorized services, reimbursed based on a VA fee schedule. The program provided outpatient care, including dental care for veterans with service-connected disabilities, saving them time and offering treatment in their hometown by a doctor of their choice. The Veterans' Benefit Act of 1957 authorized the VA to contract with private facilities for hospital care for veterans with service-connected disabilities. The Veterans Health Care Expansion Act of 1973 expanded outpatient care to nonservice-connected veterans. The Veterans Omnibus Health Care Act of 1976 addressed overcrowded conditions in VA health care facilities. The Veterans Omnibus Health Care Act of 1976 (P.L. 94-581) made changes to the fee-basis program, limiting care to specific categories of veterans. The Veterans' Health Care Amendments of 1979 (P.L. 96-22) expanded fee-basis care to veterans with nonservice-connected disabilities. The Veterans Omnibus Health Care Act of 1976 and the Veterans' Health Care Amendments of 1979 expanded fee-basis care to veterans with disabilities. The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 clarified the definition of "Veterans' Administration facilities" and authorized the VA to contract for medical care in private facilities. The VA MISSION Act amended the legal framework around existing veterans care programs, including the Veterans Choice Program. The VA MISSION Act amended existing veterans care programs and created new ones, including walk-in care. It also maintained provisions for emergency care and sharing resources with the Department of Defense. The Veterans Access, Choice and Accountability Act of 2014 (VACAA) established the temporary Veterans Choice Program (VCP) to address wait time manipulation and access issues at VHA hospitals. It also created the Veterans Choice Fund (VCF) with $10 billion in appropriations. Challenges in implementing the VCP are documented in various reports and hearings. The Surface Transportation and Veterans Health Care Choice Improvement Act of 2015 mandated the VA to consolidate existing community care programs, in response to challenges with the Veterans Choice Program. Congress introduced measures to improve access to care, such as the Improving Veterans Access to Care in the Community Act and the Veterans Choice Improvement Act of 2016. At the end of the 114th Congress, no major legislative action occurred to revamp veterans community care programs. In the 115th Congress, implementation issues regarding the Veterans Choice Program (VCP) arose, leading to the passage of P.L. 115-26 to extend the VCP. Additional funding of $4.2 billion was provided through the VA Choice and Quality Employment Act of 2017 to continue the VCP. The VA submitted a plan to consolidate community care programs to replace the VCP in October 2017. The plan, called the Veterans Coordinated Access & Rewarding Experiences (CARE) plan, focused on eligibility criteria for veterans to access care in the community. The House Veterans' Affairs Committee held a hearing on the CARE plan and other legislative proposals in October 2017. The VA Care in the Community Act (H.R. 4242) was introduced on November 3, 2017. The VA Care in the Community Act (H.R. 4242) was introduced and marked up by the HVAC. The Senate Veterans' Affairs Committee also marked up a draft measure, but no further action occurred. In the second session of the 115th Congress, provisions of various acts were combined into the VA Maintaining Internal Systems and Strengthening Integrated Outside Networks Act. The VA MISSION Act of 2018 (H.R. 5674) was introduced and passed into law as S. 2372 (P.L. 115-182) on June 6, 2018, with amendments and technical corrections made by the Department of Veterans Affairs Expiring Authorities Act of 2018 (S. 3479; P.L. 115-251). The VA MISSION Act of 2018 (P.L. 115-182) provides $5.2 billion for the VCF. The CBO estimates a total cost of $46.5 billion for implementing all provisions, including $21.4 billion for the Veterans Community Care Program and $6.7 billion for expanding the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers. The VA MISSION Act of 2018 (P.L. 115-182) provides $6.7 billion for expanding assistance to family caregivers of veterans injured or disabled before September 11, 2001. The CBO estimates that the act would increase the deficit by $5.2 billion over six years and almost $4.5 billion over 11 years. This report summarizes the major provisions of the VA MISSION Act and amendments made by the Department of Veterans Affairs Expiring Authorities Act of 2018. The report provides a summary of the VA MISSION Act of 2018, detailing amendments to current law regarding care for service-connected disabilities and disabilities of veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs are key entities referenced throughout the report. The VA MISSION Act of 2018 amends current law to provide care for veterans with service-connected disabilities, including total permanent disabilities. It establishes the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) for greater flexibility in accessing community care, hospital care, medical services, and extended care services for enrolled veterans. The VA MISSION Act of 2018 establishes the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) for broader eligibility for enrolled veterans, regardless of service-connected disability. It will replace the current Veterans Choice Program (VCP) one year after enactment. The Act requires the Secretary to set access and quality standards for medical care and extended care services, allowing the VA to enter into Veteran Care Agreements (VCAs) without typical contracting regulations. State Veterans Homes can also enter into VCAs with the VA, not considered federal contracts but still subject to relevant federal laws. Title I of the VA MISSION Act of 2018 expands eligibility for veterans to access walk-in care from private community providers, amends VA's prompt payment standards for all community care providers, requires education programs for veterans on health insurance interactions, improves information sharing with community providers, ensures competency of private community providers, and provides VA clinicians access to State Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs (PDMPs). Title I of the VA MISSION Act of 2018 expands eligibility for veterans to access walk-in care from private community providers and improves information sharing with community providers. It also grants VA clinicians access to State Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs (PDMPs) and establishes a VA Innovation for Care and Payment Center. Additionally, it allows for telemedicine care regardless of location and authorizes pilot programs for innovative payment and healthcare delivery models. The Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers is extended to pre-9/11 veterans with serious service-connected injuries. The "Caring for Our Veterans Act of 2018" amends current law to establish the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) for eligible veterans to receive hospital care, medical services, and extended care services from non-VA providers. The program will replace current provisions and require the Secretary to coordinate care provided. Section 1703 of the "Caring for Our Veterans Act of 2018" requires the Secretary to coordinate care provided through the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) for eligible veterans. This includes timely scheduling of medical appointments, ensuring continuity of care, coordinating among regional networks, and preventing lapses in care for all eligible veterans. The Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) provides eligible veterans with care through non-VA health care providers like Medicare participants, DOD and IHS medical facilities, FQHCs, and other approved providers. The Secretary can authorize care for eligible veterans through VCCP under specific conditions, subject to annual appropriations. Eligible veterans can elect to receive care through VCCP if certain criteria are met. Eligible veterans can receive care through the Veterans Community Care Program if specific conditions are met, such as the VA not offering required care, not having a full-service facility in the veteran's state, or meeting distance eligibility criteria. Eligible veterans can receive care through the Veterans Community Care Program if the VA is unable to provide care meeting access standards, the veteran's clinician agrees it's in their best interest, or the veteran elects to receive care through VCCP. The VA can authorize care through the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP) if a VA medical service line fails to meet access and quality standards. The Secretary must develop these standards, considering factors like timeliness and quality of care. The number of medical service lines compared is limited to three per facility and 36 nationwide. The Secretary must publish a notice annually with details on available care. Appeals for care decisions can be made through VHA's internal process, not the Board of Veterans' Appeals. The Secretary is authorized to develop a tiered network of eligible providers for the Veterans Community Care Program (VCCP), with contracts established through competitive bidding. Eligible veterans can choose their own VCCP health care provider, and the Secretary must ensure advanced technology for appointment scheduling. Eligible veterans can make their own appointments using advanced technology. The Secretary is responsible for scheduling appointments and can terminate contracts with health care providers for non-compliance with regulations or quality standards. The Secretary has the authority to terminate contracts with health care providers if they fail to meet contractual obligations or if their continued participation is not in the best interests of veterans or the VA. Alternative value-based reimbursement models can be used to promote high-quality care. The Secretary must collect charges for care provided to eligible veterans with third-party insurance. Recovery and collections are limited to what would be payable by a third-party payer. The section outlines copayments for eligible veterans receiving nonservice-connected care, authorizes organ transplants at non-VA facilities, and requires reporting on care provided under VCCP. The report, due within 540 days of the Caring for Our Veterans Act of 2018, and annually after, must include data on top care types not provided by VA, care frequency sought by veterans, reasons for unprovided care, VA steps taken, and VCCP care costs. The Secretary must compile data on care types, patient numbers, gaps in VCCP care, and assessments. The Secretary is required to report on gaps in care and services provided through VCCP community care networks, ways to fix these gaps, total amounts spent by the VA on care for eligible veterans, timeliness of VA referrals to VCCP networks, and timeliness of VCCP networks in accepting referrals and scheduling appointments. The report must also include data on VA medical service lines not meeting standards, use of academic affiliates and federal health care facilities, and must be submitted to SVAC and HVAC within 540 days of enactment and annually thereafter. This section of the legislation prohibits the Secretary from limiting hospital care, medical services, or extended care services under VCCP if it is in the best interest of the eligible veteran. It clarifies that no changes are made to a veteran's eligibility criteria for these services under VCCP. The effective date of VCCP implementation is tied to the exhaustion of funds in the Veterans Choice Fund. This section of the legislation amends current law to authorize the Secretary to enter into agreements with community providers known as Veterans Care Agreements (VCAs) if care cannot be feasibly delivered through VA facilities or other statutory authorities. It also requires the Secretary to continue existing contracts with American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian health care systems. The CARES program was established in 2000 to evaluate veterans' healthcare needs and realign VA infrastructure. The DNCP recommended closing seven VA facilities and eliminating duplicative services at over 30 other locations. The DNCP recommended closing VA facilities in Canandaigua, NY; Pittsburgh, PA; Lexington, KY; Cleveland, OH; Gulfport, MS; Waco, TX; and Livermore, CA.
